title-group.article-title: Causal relationship between gut microbiota and pituitary neuroendocrine tumors: a bidirectional Mendelian randomization

contrib-group.aff: https://ror.org/03s8txj32grid.412463.60000 0004 1762 6325The Second Affiliated Hospital of Harbin Medical University, Harbin, 150086 People’s Republic of China

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Previous observational studies have hinted at a connection between the gut microbiota and pituitary neuroendocrine tumors, yet the causal nature of this relationship remains uncertain.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: We employed a bidirectional Mendelian randomization to explore the potential impact of gut microbiota on the susceptibility to developing pituitary neuroendocrine tumors. Our analysis included weighted median estimator, simple model, weighted model, inverse variance-weighted, and the MR-Egger regression method for estimating causal effects and conducting sensitivity analyses. Additionally, reverse Mendelian randomization analysis was conducted on bacteria identified as causally linked to pituitary neuroendocrine tumors.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Causal relationships were identified between genetic predisposition in the gut microbiota and pituitary neuroendocrine tumors, involving 11 distinct bacterial families and genera. Notably, no significant causal effect was detected from pituitary neuroendocrine tumors on the gut microbiota, and there were no significant heterogeneities observed in instrumental variables or horizontal pleiotropy.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Through two-sample Mendelian randomization analysis, we pinpointed particular gut microbiota with a causal link to both the occurrence and prognosis of pituitary neuroendocrine tumors at the genetic prognostic level. These findings hold promise for serving as valuable biomarkers for early disease detection and as potential therapeutic targets for the management of pituitary neuroendocrine tumors.

sec.title: Supplementary Information
sec.p: The online version contains supplementary material available at 10.1007/s12672-025-02958-6.

funding-source.institution: Neurosurgery First-class Discipline Funding Project of the Second Affiliated Hospital of Harbin Medical University

custom-meta.meta-value: © Springer Science+Business Media LLC, part of Springer Nature 2025

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Pituitary neuroendocrine tumors (PitNETs) are one of the most commonly occurring benign neoplasms of the sella region [1, 2]. A series of clinical manifestations, such as neurological dysfunction, endocrine disorders, and visual impairment, are often caused by tumor compression of the surrounding tissue [3, 4]. Patients often suffer significant physical and psychological damage and carry a severe economic burden. Therefore, identifying valuable biomarkers for early detection, intervention, and prevention of PitNETs is paramount.

Gut microbiota, which includes bacteria, viruses, and fungi, refers to the collection of microorganisms that reside in the human gastrointestinal tract [5]. The critical physiological role of the gut microbiota has been implicated in the pathogenesis of various human metabolic, immune, and neurological diseases [6]. Previous researchers have demonstrated that the relationships between gut microbiota and central nervous system disorders are complex [7–11]. This research has been extended to various health conditions, including central nervous system tumors [12–14]. The Gut-brain axis has consistently attracted much attention [15]. Gut microbiota dysbiosis can cause systemic or central nervous system inflammation and produce neurotoxic metabolites, influencing the development of PitNETs [16–18]. Nevertheless, the underlying causality between the gut microbiota and the PitNETs is still unclear.

However, methodological differences and different outcome measures make research in this area challenging. Furthermore, due to the rare occurrence of intracranial neoplasms, conducting a randomized controlled trial (RCT) to examine the association between PitNETs and gut microbiota is challenging. To fill these gaps and to clarify the causality between PitNETs and gut microbiota, we performed a Mendelian randomization (MR) analysis. Using genetic variants as instrumental variables (IVs) in a RCT, MR reduces biases and inaccuracies and improves causal inferences between exposure and outcome [19]. We aim to improve our knowledge of how the gut microbiota participates in the development of PitNETs and to generate tailored therapies based on changes in the gut microbiota. The association between gut microbiota and PitNETs has been investigated in our study for the first time. Our findings suggest a plausible causative association between gut microbiota and PitNETs, highlighting the need for further investigation and tailored microbiome strategies to improve the prognosis of PitNETs.

sec.title: Study design
sec.p: In conducting the MR studies and drafting the article, we adhered to the STROBE-MR checklist [20]. Our MR research was underpinned by three core assumptions. Firstly, instrumental genetic variants were presumed to have a robust association with exposure. Secondly, potential confounding variables were assumed to be unrelated to these instrumental genetic variants. Thirdly, these instrumental genetic variants were assumed to influence outcomes solely through exposure pathways. To comprehensively investigate the involvement of gut microbiota in the etiology of PitNETs, we conducted MR studies across five distinct taxonomic levels, encompassing phylum, class, order, family, and genus. Figure 1 illustrates the research framework alongside the foundational MR assumptions.

sec.title: Data sources
sec.p: Our gut microbiota genome-wide association study (GWAS) data was derived from MiBioGen, which covered 196 taxa in total (sorted by taxonomy): 119 genera, 32 families, 20 orders, 16 classes, and 9 phyla [21].Link: https://mibiogen.gcc.rug.nl/. The GWAS data for PitNETs from the FinnGen European cohort study [22]. Round 9 of the FinnGen study included 1,402 PitNETs cases and 375,875 controls. Link: https://r9.finngen.fi/. PitNETs endpoints were defined by the International Classification of Diseases, 10th Revision (ICD-10). D35.2 are the ICD-10 codes for PitNETs. The FinnGen GWAS data had been subject to approval by the FinnGen committee.

sec.title: Selection of genetic instruments
sec.p: Single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) were then filtered by the following criteria: (1) We set a genome-wide significance threshold of p < 1 × 10 − 5 when using gut microbiota as an exposure to obtain sufficient SNPs [23]. (2) The Linkage disequilibrium (LD) test was performed with plink, and LD r2 < 0.001 within a window of 10000 kb was assumed to guarantee the independency of the selected IVs [24]. (3) To avoid weak instrumental bias, the F statistic was estimated for each SNP, and SNPs with F < 10 were removed [25]. (4) The harmonization process removed the mismatched or intermediate palindromic allele frequency SNPs.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: This study used inverse variance weighted (IVW) as the main analysis to preliminarily assess the potentially causative effect of each phenotype on PitNETs’ risk. To ensure the reliability of the results, the Weighted Mode, MR-Egger, weighted median estimator (WME), and Simple Mode analyses are used to complement the IVW estimation [26, 27].

Cochran’s Q statistic was performed to quantify and assess for possible heterogeneity, and the MR intercept test was used to estimate horizontal pleiotropies. A leave-one-out analysis was conducted to detect and eliminate any outliers that might have an independent effect on the observable causality. The MR-PRESSO test was also performed for outlier detection and heterogeneity adjustment in the case of notable MR estimates. If heterogeneity was detected between IVs, outliers were excluded and the MR analysis was replicated. To eliminate the influence of confounders, we further investigated whether the chosen SNPs with meaningful MR estimates in this research were associated with other PitNETs’ risk factors (http://www.phenoscanner.medschl.cam.ac.uk). The study retested the causal effects to determine their significance after excluding the confounding SNPs. Since the robustness of MR analysis is compromised by sample overlapping, an online tool (https://sb452.shinyapps.io/overlap/) has been employed to calculate bias and type I error rates for MR with sample overlapping [28].

The selection of MR methods is guided by three key principles [29]: (1) Prioritizing the use of IVW estimates when heterogeneity and pleiotropies are absent; (2) If only heterogeneity is present without pleiotropies, preference is given to results from the WME method (although the random effects model of IVW can also be considered); (3) For each outcome, we adjusted the P-values for the false discovery rate (FDR) based on different categories of gut microbiota, obtaining the corresponding P_FDR. In our analysis, when P < 0.05 and P_FDR < 0.1, it was considered that there was a significant causal relationship between the exposure and the outcome. Conversely, when P < 0.05 and P_FDR ≥ 0.1, it was regarded as a potential correlation between the two [24, 30].

To explore whether PitNETs exert a causal influence on specific bacterial strains, we undertook a reverse MR analysis. Here, PitNETs served as the exposure, while identified causal bacterial strains were treated as outcomes. To achieve this, we utilized SNPs associated with PitNETs as IVs, following the settings and procedures consistent with forward MR methodologies [31]. Among these, we set the prominent threshold for the full genome to p < 1 × 10⁻5 to screen for SNPs. The Two-Sample-MR package [32] of the R software (version 4.3.1) was predominantly employed for all the aforementioned analyses.

sec.title: An overview of IVs in taxa
sec.p: Each 196 bacterial taxa received multiple SNPs as proxies through genome-wide significance threshold screening (p < 1 × 10 − 5), LD test, harmonization, MR-PRESSO test, and F-statistic verification. All SNPs that were identified as outliers by MR-PRESSO (global trial: p < 0.05) were removed. The retained SNPs all had F-statistics greater than 10, indicating a strong correlation between the IVs and the corresponding bacterial taxon. Supplement Table 1 displays the final list of retained SNPs and their F-statistics.

sec.title: Associations of genetically gut bacterial with PitNETs
sec.p: Figure 2 shows the results from the preliminary analyses for associations between genetically linked gut microbiota taxa and PitNETs risk. All estimates were expressed in terms of ORs per SDs increase in exposure. We found a causal relationship between two microbial classes, one microbial family, five microbial genera, one microbial order, and two microbial phyla of the gut microbiota and glioblastoma (Table 1).

caption.p: The results from the preliminary analyses for associations between genetically linked gut microbiota taxa and PitNETs risk
MR results of causal effects between gut microbiota and PitNETs

sec.p: OR odds ratio, CI confidence interval, IVW inverse-variance weighted, WM weighted median.

As shown in Fig. 3, among these 11 taxa, class.Negativicutes (IVW OR = 1.85, 95%CI 1.20–2.85, P = 0.005, P_FDR = 0.087), genus.Eggerthella (IVW OR = 1.42, 95% CI 1.10–1.84, P = 0.006, P_FDR = 0.762), genus.Ruminiclostridium5 (IVW OR = 1.58, 95% CI 1.01–2.45, P = 0.043, P_FDR = 0.994), order.Selenomonadales (IVW OR = 1.85, 95% CI 1.20–2.85, P = 0.005, P_FDR = 0.109), and phylum.Euryarchaeota (IVW OR = 1.28, 95% CI 1.04–1.57, P = 0.022, P_FDR = 0.099) had an indicative positive causal effect on the risk of PitNETs, whereas class.Mollicutes (IVW OR = 0.65, 95% CI 0.47–0.92, P = 0.014, P_FDR = 0.112), family.Alcaligenaceae (IVW OR = 0.50, 95%CI 0.32–0.80, P = 0.004, P_FDR = 0.095), genus.Fusicatenibacter (IVW OR = 0.65, 95% CI 0.43–0.99, P = 0.046, P_FDR = 0.994), genus.RuminococcaceaeUCG004 (IVW OR = 0.72, 95% CI 0.52–1.00, P = 0.047, P_FDR = 0.994), genus.Streptococcus (IVW OR = 0.65, 95% CI 0.44–0.96, P = 0.029, P_FDR = 0.994), and phylum.Tenericutes (IVW OR = 0.65, 95% CI 0.47–0.92, P = 0.014, P_FDR = 0.099) tended to reduce the risk of PitNETs causally. With the exception of the genus.Ruminiclostridium5 and the phylum.Euryarchaeota, other MR analyses of the remaining nine taxa, including MR-Egger, WM, weighted mode and simple mode, agreed with the respective IVW results. For the genus.Ruminiclostridium5 and the phylum.Euryarchaeota, the effect estimated by MR-Egger, although not statistically significant, was in the opposite direction to the results of the other four MR analyses. Theoretically, this should lead to a reduction of the significance threshold at the genome level and a more stringent selection of independent variables [33]. However, this process was impossible due to the small number of corresponding SNPs remaining. It is acceptable to retain the IVW estimate for the genus.Ruminiclostridium5 and the phylum.Euryarchaeota, as the causal effects analyzed by IVW are more accurate than those of MR-Egger, assuming no horizontal pleiotropy [27].

caption.p: Associations of genetically proxied gut bacterial taxa with PitNETs

sec.title: Detection of potential pleiotropy and sensitivity analyses
sec.p: For the sake of objectivity, several steps were taken for testing the sensitivity of the MR analysis and for detecting possible pleiotropy of the IVs per phenotype. We then removed these outliers using the MR-PRESSO method. Notably, the IVs of the above 11 taxa did not detect any pleiotropic outliers that could have a causal relationship to PitNETs. In addition, the 11 taxa did not show any evidence of heterogeneity, as indicated by Cochran’s Q test. All P values were greater than 0.05, as shown in Table 2. Scatter plots and funnel plots for these 11 taxa are shown in Fig. 4 and Supplement Fig. 1. For these 11 taxa, the intercepts of the MR-Egger regression did not provide any evidence of horizontal pleiotropy. The analysis revealed that the results remained consistent regardless of which SNP was removed, as demonstrated in Supplement Fig. 2 through leave-one-out analysis. More importantly, after searching the PhenoScanner, no SNPs were found in these 11 taxa associated with confounding factors. To summarize, the robustness of our MR analyses is reflected in the results of all these sensitivity analyses.

caption.p: The scatter plots for a several of gut microbial on PitNETs
Sensitivity analysis for significant and nominal significant estimates

sec.title: Bidirectional causal effects between gut microbiota and PitNETs' risk
sec.p: We utilized PitNETs as the exposure and identified causal bacteria as the outcome to assess any potential reverse causation effects. Employing five widely recognized MR methods, we determined that PitNETs did not exhibit significant causal associations with the identified gut microbiota.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: To date, this is the first MR study to use large-scale gut microbial genomic data that explores whether gut microbes causally influence risk of PitNETs. Based on the largest GWAS dataset, the Two-sample MR analysis identified 11 bacterial taxa with potential causative effects on PitNETs, highlighting the gut microbiome’s important role in developing PitNETs. Given that the incidence of pituitary adenoma is approximately 77–94 cases per 100,000 individuals, whereas the overall annual incidence of craniopharyngioma in both adults and children is only about 0.5–2.0 cases per 1,000,000 individuals, and considering that the FinnGen dataset predominantly comprises adults while craniopharyngioma primarily affects children, we excluded craniopharyngioma from our analysis after thorough consideration. This exclusion is unlikely to have a significant impact on our overall findings.

The association between genetic susceptibility of the gut microbiota and tumors has been extensively investigated, primarily focusing on gastrointestinal tumors due to their shared ecosystem [34, 35]. Recently, there is a growing interest in exploring the link between the gut microbiota and endocrine tumors such as thyroid cancer and endometrial cancer [36–38]. PitNETs rank as the third most prevalent intracranial tumor and are relatively common endocrine tumors, with an incidence rate as high as 10% [39, 40]. Despite significant advancements in neuroendoscopic surgery, managing certain types of PitNETs remains challenging for clinicians [41]. Therefore, conducting large-scale GWAS studies to investigate the relationship between the gut microbiome and PitNETs could yield valuable insights into the mechanisms and potential drug targets involved in gut microbiota-mediated development of PitNETs.

A growing body of research is finding possible links between the gut microbiota selected for our study and other oncological and endocrine diseases. We investigated whether there is a link between gut microbiota and PitNETs through MR analysis. The findings indicate a strong relationship and potential interaction between gut microbiota and PitNETs. Research indicates that the intestinal flora plays a role in the onset and progression of PitNETs, yet the precise mechanism remains unclear. Studies have revealed an enrichment of Clostridium innocuum and a decrease in abundance of Oscillibacter sp. 57_20 and Fusobacterium mortiferum in patients with pituitary adenomas [42]. Additionally, investigations have demonstrated significant enrichment of Oscillibacter, Enterobacter, Alistipes shahii, Odoribacter splanchnicus, Enterobacter sp. DC1, and Enterobacter sp. 940 PEND in patients with growth hormone-secreting pituitary adenomas (GHPA) [43]. Similarly, another study identified differences in the composition and quantity of intestinal flora among patients with GHPA, non-functioning pituitary adenomas (NFPA), and healthy controls [44].

Similar to prior observational studies, our MR investigation also identified 11 taxa, encompassing 5 genera, 1 family, 1 order, 2 classes, and 2 phyla, that were causally linked to PitNETs. Class.Mollicutes are a group of bacteria that lack a cell wall, the representative member of which is Mycoplasma. Research has indicated associations between Mycoplasma and tumor development in the brain, breast, lymphatic system, as well as various organs of the genitourinary, respiratory, gastrointestinal, and urinary tracts [45, 46]. This could be attributed to the ability of mycoplasma infection to initiate an inflammatory response within cells, consequently resulting in cellular DNA damage and mutations, thus elevating the likelihood of tumor development. Previous research has also demonstrated a link between mycoplasma and PitNETs, possibly through the activation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis by inflammatory mediators [47, 48]. The phylum.Tenericutes represents a broader taxonomic category encompassing various bacteria, including Mollicutes. Consequently, similar to class.Mollicutes, phylum.Tenericutes could potentially influence the onset and progression of PitNETs by modulating the host’s immune system and inflammatory response, thereby impacting the activation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis and even the tumor microenvironment [49].

Class.Negativicutes are a type of Gram-negative bacteria. Previous research has indicated a correlation between class.Negativicutes in oral flora and the occurrence and progression of esophageal cancer [50]. Gram-negative bacteria have been closely associated with tumors such as lung cancer and hematological malignancies. The gut microbiota could potentially influence the development of these tumors by modulating the host’s immune system and eliciting inflammatory responses [51, 52]. Family.Alcaligenaceae is a bacterial family belonging to class.Negativicutes, all of which are Gram-negative bacteria. Its potential impact on tumor occurrence could involve inducing inflammatory reactions, releasing inflammatory mediators, and influencing the body’s immune system [53]. Order.Selenomonadales is also a type of Gram-negative bacteria that has been found to be significantly increased in prostate cancer patients and is closely related to the occurrence of prostate cancer [54]. Furthermore, genus.Eggerthella, a Gram-negative bacterial genus, has been closely linked to the development of colorectal cancer and non-small cell lung cancer [55]. Lipopolysaccharide (LPS) produced by Gram-negative bacteria has been shown to promote pituitary tumor growth and hormone production by inducing interleukin (IL)−6 production in a dose-dependent manner [56].

Genus.Fusicatenibacter, a member of the genus.Ruminococcaceae, is typically an anaerobic bacterium associated with neurodegeneration [57, 58], immune system disorders [59], and tumor [60, 61]. It is plausible that genus.Fusicatenibacter could modulate the body’s immune system, immune response, or metabolism via the brain-gut axis, thereby potentially influencing the occurrence of PitNETs [15]. Genus.RuminococcaceaeUCG004, a bacterium commonly inhabiting the intestines, has previously been found to be associated with the occurrence of various tumors [62]. Interestingly, one study identified it as a protective factor against primary liver cancer [63].

Consistent with these findings, our MR study revealed a negative correlation between this bacterium and the occurrence of PitNETs. We hypothesize that it may influence the occurrence of PitNETs by modulating body metabolism, impacting the immune system, eliciting immune responses, and affecting the tumor microenvironment. Likewise, genus.Rumiclostridium 5, a prevalent intestinal parasite bacterium, is closely associated with gastrointestinal tumors such as esophageal cancer [64] and pancreatic cancer [62]. Its potential influence on the occurrence of PitNETs could involve affecting the body’s immunity, inflammation, metabolism, and other factors. Genus.Streptococcus, belonging to the order Cocci and the family.Streptococcus, is a common bacterium found in the body and has been implicated as a significant pathogenic bacterium in senile colorectal cancer [65]. Streptococcus may influence tumorigenesis by modulating multiple signaling pathways [66].

The pituitary tumor microenvironment encompasses various non-tumor cells, including immune cells, stromal cells, and endothelial cells, along with enzymes and signaling molecules such as cytokines, chemokines, and growth factors. These components surround tumor cells and have the potential to impact the occurrence and biological behavior of pituitary tumors [67]. The gut microbiota and its metabolites can influence the onset and progression of PitNETs by reshaping the tumor microenvironment and modulating key signaling pathways in cancer cells and various immune cells [68]. Studies have demonstrated that the intestinal flora of patients with GHPA may foster tumor growth by modulating the immune system [44].

The gut microbiota-brain axis encompasses various components such as the gut microbiota and its metabolites, the enteric nervous system, the sympathetic and parasympathetic branches within the autonomic nervous system, the neuroimmune system, the neuroendocrine system, and the central nervous system. Moreover, there are five communication pathways facilitating interaction between gut flora and the brain, including the gut-brain neural network, the neuroendocrine-hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis, the gut immune system, neurotransmitters synthesized by gut bacteria, and neurotransmitters synthesized by gut bacteria. The genesis of PitNETs is primarily triggered by neural, endocrine, and immune signaling pathways [69, 70]. In terms of endocrine mechanisms, the gut-brain axis, particularly the Hypothalamic-Pituitary-Adrenal axis, plays a crucial role in investigating the involvement of gut flora in the development of PitNETs. Fusicatenibacter has the capability to produce short-chain fatty acids, which in turn can influence PitNETs by modulating the activity of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis [71, 72]. Therefore, the gut-brain axis represents a significant mechanism through which intestinal flora may contribute to the onset of PitNETs.

Indeed, our study has several limitations that warrant consideration. First, because of the aggregated nature of the GWAS data obtained for PitNETs, it is impossible to analyze the data separately for PitNETs. Second, our results are subject to some error due to the rarity of intracranial tumors, and analysis of data from larger samples is needed to confirm our findings further. The study demonstrates the robust association between gut microbiota and the risk of PitNETs, as a series of sensitivity analyses confirmed the strength of the study’s causal estimates. Third, all genomic analysis data utilized in this research were obtained from European populations, raising uncertainty regarding the generalizability of our findings to populations beyond Europe. Although the craniopharyngioma component has been excluded and the diagnostic code is only identified as PitNETs, which has minimal impact on the results, we should still be aware that the results may still be subject to some selection bias.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In summary, this study has shown by MR analysis that multiple gut microbiota may play a role in the development of PitNETs, providing a theoretical basis to guide clinical practice and suggesting future research directions. It is hoped that this will draw greater attention from clinicians and researchers to the monitoring of the gut microbiome in preventing PitNETs, helping to identify additional risk predictors and potential pathogenic mechanisms, and providing new insights into the diagnosis and risk intervention of PitNETs.

notes.title: Author contributions
notes.p: Wencai Wang, Menghao Liu, and Zun Wang: designed the research; Wencai Wang: collected and organized data; Wencai Wang: analyzed the data; Wencai Wang, Menghao Liu, and Zun Wang: drafted the manuscript; Wencai Wang, Wei Ye, and Xianfeng Li: contributed to the critical revision of the manuscript. Xianfeng Li: Funding acquisition.All authors contributed to the manuscript and approved the submitted version.

notes.title: Funding
notes.p: This work was supported in part by grants from Neurosurgery First-class Discipline Funding Project of the Second Affiliated Hospital of Harbin Medical University.

notes.title: Data availability
notes.p: The datasets analyzed during the current study are available in the MiBioGen repository, https://mibiogen.gcc.rug.nl/, and the FinnGen repository, https://r9.finngen.fi/.

notes.title: Ethics approval and consent to participate
notes.p: All studies used in the analysis received ethical approval from their respective institutional review boar.

notes.title: Competing interests
notes.p: The authors declare no competing interests.
